text: Mitrephora maingayi is a species of plant in the family Annonaceae. It is native to Bangladesh, Borneo, Cambodia, Laos, Peninsular Malaysia, Myanmar, Sumatra, and Vietnam. Joseph Hooker and Thomas Thomson, the British botanists who first formally described the species, named it in honor of Alexander Carroll Maingay, the British botanist who collected the specimen they examined. ==Description== It is a tree. Its leaves are 3-7 by 1.25-2.5 inches and come to a point at their tips. The leaves are smooth and shiny on their upper surfaces. Its petioles are 0.25-0.5 inches long. Its pendulous flowers are yellow with red highlights. Its flowers have 3 brown sepals that are covered in dense wooly hair. ===Reproductive biology=== Using the synonymous name, Mitrephora teysmannii, Yunyun Shao and Fengxia Xu report that the pollen of M. maingayi is shed as permanent tetrads. ==References== maingayi Category:Flora of Bangladesh Category:Flora of Borneo Category:Flora of Cambodia Category:Flora of Laos Category:Flora of Peninsular Malaysia Category:Flora of Myanmar Category:Flora of Sumatra Category:Flora of Vietnam Category:Plants described in 1872
